item.title: Poland Delivers Rate-Cut Surprise With Inflation Set to Ease
item.description: Poland’s central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates after a one-month pause and said inflation is likely to ease within its target in the coming months, raising expectations that monetary easing is set to continue.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Shelves of household products on display at the Hala Mirowska market hall in downtown Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Polish inflation fell to the central bank’s target for the first time in three years in March even as policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady due to concerns over resurgent price growth later in 2024.

item.title: France Urgently Needs to Get a Grip on Finances, Auditor Warns
item.description: France must urgently take steps to rein in public finances or soon be forced into painful austerity, the country’s audit court said, highlighting the difficulties for a minority government already at risk of collapse over fiscal plans.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: Beijing Braces for US Trade Deals That Aim to Shut Out China
item.description: The trade truce between Washington and Beijing may be holding for now, but China is increasingly wary about what’s happening elsewhere: US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and container ships at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: Romania Pushes Austerity Plan to Cut EU’s Widest Budget Gap
item.description: Romania’s premier unveiled a package of tax hikes and wage freezes that aims to cut the budget deficit to below 6% of GDP next year and avoid a credit rating downgrade to junk.

item.title: IMF Sees Nigeria Fiscal Deficit Widening on Lower Oil Income
item.description: Nigerian economic reforms have improved investor sentiment but the nation’s finances are being hurt by lower oil prices that will widen its budget gap this year, said the International Monetary Fund.

item.title: US Private Payrolls Fall for First Time in Two Years in ADP Data
item.description: Employment at US companies fell in June for the first time in more than two years, reflecting a drop in services payrolls that may raise concerns about a more pronounced labor market slowdown.

item.title: US Wants Vietnam to Pay Higher Tariff Based on Foreign Content

item.title: South African Treasury Warns Against Changing SARB Ownership
item.description: Changing the ownership structure of the South African Reserve Bank could generate fears among investors about expropriation and create more uncertainty about property rights, according to the National Treasury.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian carries a colorful umbrella as she passes street traders on a road near the headquarters of the South African Reserve Bank, center, in the central business district (CBD) in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, Dec. 15, 2015. South Africa's new Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan said he'll shore up public finances to regain market trust and show credit-rating companies the government is serious about managing debt.

item.title: Japan’s Record Tax Haul Leaves Questions Over Ishiba’s Pledge
item.description: Japan’s tax revenues hit a record of around ¥75.2 trillion ($524 billion) in the fiscal year ended March, surpassing government forecasts by ¥1.8 trillion. But the windfall still left questions over how Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba will fund his cash handouts, a key election pledge.
